content: Investments Asked by AnonymousAsked on 21 Sep 2019Should I stop diversifying and reallocate my investments into fewer places?I'm a 20yo NSF earning 560/month, and I'm saving 140, investing 147 into a robo-advisor with a moderately aggressive risk profile, investing 154 into a savings insurance, and spending the rest each month. I have other investments into places like Republic (for startups) and Ethis.co (for property development crowdfunding).If it helps, I've got a fully paid scholarship for uni so saving up for the near future isn't really a priority. I'm looking at marriage/housing expenses. Any suggestions?1 answerAnswerBump0

Elijah Lee, Independent Financial Advisor at Phillip Securities (Jurong East Lite)Top Contributor (Sep)Level 9. God of WisdomAnswered on 21 Sep 2019Hi anon. Look at building your rainy day fund first. It is still important to have one in the event of emergencies. 6 months of expenses at a minimum, and 12 if possible.Secondly, please look into CI coverage and hospitalization cover, I note you have a savings insurance, but as you will step into the workforce in around 5 years, getting yourself covered for CI if you can afford it will be more important compared to saving up a sum of money.Once that is done, you need to have an idea of the timeline you are looking at for housing/marriage. You will want to take a minimal risk if you intend to have the funds ready in 5 years or less, and can afford a diversified portfolio with moderate risk if you are preparing for something 5 to 10 years down the road. For this, numerous options are available to you as a retail investor, such as UT, bonds, shares, etc.0 comments6
